---

To resolve this issue, you can try these steps:

1. Restart your IDE to ensure it picks up the latest configuration
2. If that doesn't work, you might need to explicitly configure your IDE to use the project's RuboCop configuration. In VS Code (which I assume you're using based on the Ruby LSP setup), you can add this to your workspace settings:

```json
{
    "rubyLsp.rubocop": {
        "useBundler": true,
        "configFilePath": ".rubocop.yml"
    }
}
```

3. You can also try running `bundle exec rubocop -D` to see which configuration file RuboCop is actually using when run from the command line, to verify it's picking up your local config.

Could you tell me:
1. Which specific rules are being highlighted incorrectly in your IDE?
2. Are you using VS Code or a different IDE?

This will help me provide more specific guidance for your setup.

---

The issue is that Sorbet can't understand the dynamically defined methods from the plugin system. Here's how to fix this:

1. **Create RBI files for the dynamically defined methods**
2. **Use Tapioca to generate RBI files for the plugin methods**

Let me create the necessary RBI files:


---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="edit_file">

<details><summary>Tool use: **edit_file** â€¢ Edit file: sorbet/rbi/code_teams.rbi</summary>

I will create an RBI file that defines the dynamically created methods from the plugin system

**Chunk 1**
Lines added: 17, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,17 @@
- 
+ # typed: strong
+ 
+ module CodeTeams
+   class Team
+     # Dynamically defined methods from plugins
+     # These are created by Plugin.all_plugins.each { |plugin| define_method(plugin.data_accessor_name) }
+     
+     # Identity plugin method
+     sig { returns(CodeTeams::Plugins::Identity::IdentityStruct) }
+     def identity; end
+     
+     # Add other plugin methods here as they are created
+     # For example, if you have a GitHub plugin:
+     # sig { returns(CodeTeams::Plugins::Github::GithubStruct) }
+     # def github; end
+   end
+ end 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

```
  Changed strictness of sorbet/rbi/gems/rexml@3.4.1.rbi to &#96;typed: false&#96; (confl
icting with DSL files)

  Changed strictness of sorbet/rbi/gems/tapioca@0.16.11.rbi to &#96;typed: false&#96; (c
onflicting with DSL files)

All operations performed in working directory.
Please review changes and commit them.

Finding all unresolved constants, this may take a few seconds... Nothing to do
This project is now set up for use with Sorbet and Tapioca

The sorbet/ folder should exist and look something like this:

â”œâ”€â”€ config             # Default options to be passed to Sorbet on every run
â””â”€â”€ rbi/
  â”œâ”€â”€ annotations/     # Type definitions pulled from the rbi-central repository
  â”œâ”€â”€ gems/            # Autogenerated type definitions for your gems
  â””â”€â”€ todo.rbi         # Constants which were still missing after RBI generation
â””â”€â”€ tapioca/
  â”œâ”€â”€ config.yml       # Default options to be passed to Tapioca
  â””â”€â”€ require.rb       # A file where you can make requires from gems that might
 be needed for gem RBI gener
ation
                            
Please check this folder into version control.

ğŸ¤” What's next

1. Many Ruby applications use metaprogramming DSLs to dynamically generate const
ants and methods.
  To generate type definitions for any DSLs in your application, run:

  bin/tapioca dsl

2. Check whether the constants in the sorbet/rbi/todo.rbi file actually exist in
 your project.
  It is possible that some of these constants are typos, and leaving them in tod
o.rbi will
  hide errors in your application. Ideally, you should be able to remove all def
initions
  from this file and delete it.

3. Typecheck your project:

  bundle exec srb tc

  There should not be any typechecking errors.

4. Upgrade a file marked "# typed: false" to "# typed: true".
  Then, run: bundle exec srb tc and try to fix any errors.

  You can use Spoom to bump files for you:

  spoom bump --from false --to true

  To learn more about Spoom, visit: https://github.com/Shopify/spoom

5. Add signatures to your methods with sig. To learn how, read: https://sorbet.o
rg/docs/sigs

Documentation
We recommend skimming these docs to get a feel for how to use Sorbet:
- Gradual Type Checking: https://sorbet.org/docs/gradual
- Enabling Static Checks: https://sorbet.org/docs/static
- RBI Files: https://sorbet.org/docs/rbi

```
</details>
</tool-use>
